The imperial way is far-reaching, and the imperial records are vast. From the beginning of the Poxie era, to the beginning of the Xuanyuan era when the emperor wore robes,
the purpose was to govern the people and to demarcate the territories.
When Tang Yao received the mandate of Heaven, his virtue shone on the four borders, and when Yu Shun received the map of the land, his virtue flowed to the nine regions.
From then on, only the records of past events were transmitted in vain, and listening to the past repairs, only the history of recording words was heard.
How could it be like when the Way exists and the world is without action?
When our great Tang dynasty ruled the world, it seized the opportunity and unified the six directions, illuminating and protecting the four emperors.
The profound transformation flowed widely, and the auspicious wind blew far. It shared the covering and carrying of the universe, and equaled the wind and rain in nourishing.

And the Eastern Yi offering tribute, the Western Rong submitting, establishing the enterprise, transmitting the governance, dispelling chaos and restoring order, it is certainly surpassing the previous kings and encompassing the generations before.

With the same written language and shared norms, the ultimate governance and spiritual achievements cannot be praised without records, and how can the flourishing deeds be illuminated without proclamation?

Now, the four continents illuminated by the sun and moon are located in the middle of the trichiliocosm. All Buddha-World-Honored Ones manifest their teachings here, appearing in the world and passing into extinction, guiding sages and guiding ordinary beings.
Mount Sumeru (means Wonderful High Mountain in Tang).

Formerly called Mount Sumeru and Mount Sumeru, all of which are abbreviated forms. It is composed of the four treasures, located in the great ocean, based on the golden wheel, illuminated by the sun and moon, and frequented by the gods.
The seven mountains and seven seas surround it, standing in a row.
The seawater between the mountains possesses the eight virtues.
Outside the seven golden mountains is the salty sea.
The habitable areas in the ocean are roughly divided into four continents.

The Eastern Videha Continent, formerly called Poluoti, also called Pufu Yandai, is erroneous. The Southern JambudvÄ«pa Continent, formerly called Yanfu Ti Zhou, also called Yemu Fu Zhou, is erroneous. The Western GodÄnÄ«ya Continent, formerly called Guya Ni, also called Di Gan Ni, is erroneous. The Northern Kuru Continent, formerly called Yutu Dan Yue, also called Qilou, is erroneous.

When a golden wheel king rules over the four continents, a silver wheel king is separated from the Northern Kuru, a copper wheel king excludes the Northern Kuru and Western GodÄnÄ«ya, and an iron wheel king only rules over JambudvÄ«pa.

As for the wheel-turning king, when he is about to ascend the great throne, according to his blessings, there is a great wheel treasure that floats in the air and comes to respond to him. It is moved by the feelings of gold, silver, copper, and iron, and the territory is divided into four, three, two, and one. Based on the auspicious signs that precede it, it is taken as his title.
Then, the central land of JambudvÄ«pa is Lake Anavatapta (meaning free from heat and suffering).

It is located south of GandhamÄdana and north of the Great Snow Mountains, and is eight hundred li in circumference.
Its banks are adorned with gold, silver, lapis lazuli, and crystal.
Golden sand spreads out, and the clear waves are like a mirror.
The eighth-stage bodhisattvas, by the power of their vows, transform into dragon kings and dwell there.

They emerge with cool, clear water to supply JambudvÄ«pa.ğŸ”½Therefore, from the silver bull's mouth on the east side of the lake, the Gaá¹…gÄ River (formerly called the Ganges River, erroneously) flows out, encircles the lake once, and enters the South Sea;

On the west side of the pond, flowing out from the mouth of a lapis lazuli horse, is the Bhacchu River (formerly known as the Bocha River, erroneously), which circles the pond once and enters the northwest sea;

On the north side of the pond, flowing out from the mouth of a crystal lion, is the Sita River (formerly known as the Sida River, erroneously), which circles the pond once and enters the northeast sea. Some say it flows underground and emerges from the Jishi Mountains, which is the source of the rivers in China.
At that time, there was no universal monarch to rule the world, so the land of JambudvÄ«pa had four rulers.

In the south, the elephant ruler, where it is hot and humid and elephants thrive; in the west, the treasure ruler, bordering the sea and filled with treasures; in the north, the horse ruler, where it is cold and strong and horses are abundant; in the east, the human ruler, where it is harmonious and pleasant and there are many people.

Therefore, the countries of the elephant ruler are restless and studious, especially skilled in strange arts. They wear a sideways hat and bare the right shoulder. The head has a topknot with four hanging strands. They live in clans and villages, with multi-story houses.

The land of the treasure masters has no rites and righteousness, values wealth and bribes, wears short-sleeved left-collared robes, shaves their hair and grows long beards, lives in walled cities, and values the profits of accumulating wealth.
The customs of the horse masters are naturally fierce and violent, their nature is cruel and murderous, they live in felt tents and follow their herds with their birds of prey.

The land of the human masters has customs that are ingenious and wise, with benevolence and righteousness shining brightly, they wear hats and robes with right-collared openings, their carriages and clothing are well-ordered, they value stability and consider moving to be heavy, and they value accumulating wealth.
The customs of the three masters consider the east to be superior. Their houses have doors facing east, and they face east to pay respects in the morning.
The land of the human masters considers facing south to be honorable.
The customs and styles of the regions differ greatly.
As for the rites of ruler and minister, superiors and inferiors, and the ceremonial forms of written rules, the land of the human masters cannot surpass it.
The teachings of purifying the mind and freeing from burdens, and the teachings of escaping from birth and death, in the land of the elephant masters, their principles are superior.

All of these are based on the scriptures and edicts, inquiring about the customs of various lands, extensively connecting the present and the past, and carefully examining what has been seen and heard.

However, Buddhism arose in the West, and the Dharma flowed to the East. In the process of translation, the sounds became distorted, and the language and words became erroneous. When the sounds are distorted, the meaning is lost. When the language is erroneous, the principle is deviated from.
Therefore, it is said:
It is necessary to rectify names, valuing the absence of error.
People have different natures of rigidity and flexibility, and their spoken sounds are not the same. This is related to the climate of the land and also due to local customs.
As for the differences in mountains, rivers, and products, and the variations in customs and human nature, the national histories of the lands of human rulers are detailed.
The customs of the horse people and the regions of the treasure people are fully recorded in the historical documents, and can be briefly mentioned.

As for the country of the elephant king, it has not been known since ancient times. Some records say the land is hot and humid, or that the customs are kind and compassionate. There are some local records, but they cannot be fully known. How could it be that the Way has a place to be hidden? It is certainly the case that the world has a course of change.

Therefore, it is known that those who follow the law to return to civilization and come as guests to drink the benefits, cross heavy dangers and pay tribute to the Jade Gate, and offer strange things and pay homage to the Purple Palace, are indeed difficult to speak of.
For this reason, I traveled far in search of the Way, and in the gaps of seeking instruction, I recorded the customs.
From the Black Mountains onwards,

Although the barbarians share the same ancestry, they are divided into many groups, with boundaries and territories, mostly settled.
They build cities and work on farming and raising livestock;

When people die, their bodies are cremated, and there is no fixed mourning period.
They shave their heads, cut off their ears, and tear their clothes. They slaughter livestock to make sacrifices to the spirits of the dead.

Starting from the nearest place outside the old territory of Gaochang, the first is the country of Agni (formerly called Wu-chi).
The country of Agni is more than 600 li from east to west and more than 400 li from south to north.
The capital of the country is 6 or 7 li in circumference.
It is surrounded by mountains on four sides, and the roads are dangerous, making it easy to defend.
Springs and streams crisscross, and water is diverted for irrigation.
The land is suitable for millet, sorghum, winter wheat, fragrant dates, grapes, pears, crabapples, and other fruits.
The climate is mild and pleasant, and the customs are honest and straightforward.
The written language is based on that of India, with slight variations in silk and satin.
They wear felt robes and cut their hair without caps.
They use gold coins, silver coins, and small copper coins as currency.
The king is a native of the country, brave but lacking in strategy, fond of boasting about his conquests, with no central authority in the country and the laws not strictly enforced.

There are more than ten monasteries with over two thousand monks, who study the teachings of the Hinayana school of the Sarvastivadins. The sutras and precepts are followed as in India, and those who study them recite them in their original texts.
Their conduct and discipline are pure and diligent.
However, they eat the three kinds of impure food, which is a hindrance to the gradual teachings.

From here, going southwest for more than two hundred li, crossing a small mountain and two large rivers, in the west one reaches a flat plain. Going for more than seven hundred li, one arrives at the country of Khotan (formerly called Qiuci).
The country of Khotan is more than one thousand li from east to west and more than six hundred li from south to north.

The capital city is seventeen or eighteen li in circumference, suitable for millet and wheat, with glutinous rice, producing grapes and pomegranates, with plenty of pears, crabapples, peaches, and apricots.
The land produces gold, copper, iron, lead, and tin.
The climate is mild, and the customs are simple.
The written language is based on India, with slight changes.
Stringed instruments and music are especially good among various countries.
The clothing is brocade and hemp, with shaved hair and caps.
The currency is gold coins, silver coins, and small copper coins.
The king is of the Kuá¹£Äá¹‡a race, with limited wisdom and strategy, pressured by powerful ministers.
Their custom is to press a child's head with wood, wanting it to be flat.
There are over a hundred monasteries with more than five thousand monks, studying the teachings of the HÄ«nayÄna school of the SarvÄstivÄda.
The scriptures, teachings, and precepts are based on India, and those who study and recite them use the original texts.
They still adhere to the gradual teachings and eat the three pure foods.
The people compete in their accomplishments.
In front of the Heavenly Shrine north of the eastern border city, there is a large dragon pond.
The dragons change their forms and mate with mares, giving birth to dragon colts that are unruly and difficult to ride.
The offspring of the dragon colts are then tame and rideable. This is why this country produces many good horses.
According to what I have heard from the elders:
In recent times, there was a king named Golden Flower. His governance was clear and discerning, and he moved the dragon to ride it.
When the king was about to pass away, he whipped the dragon's ears. The dragon then hid itself and has not been seen since.
There are no wells in the city, so they take water from that pond.

The dragon transforms into a human and has relations with women, giving birth to sons who are fierce and run as fast as galloping horses.ğŸ”½In this way, they gradually interbred, and everyone became dragon-like. Relying on their strength, they became arrogant and did not obey the king's orders.
The king then incited the Tujue people to kill the people of this city, young and old alike, leaving almost no survivors.
The city is now in ruins and deserted.
More than 40 li to the north of the deserted city, bordering a mountain and across a river, there are two monasteries with the same name of Zhaohuli, distinguished as East and West.
The Buddha images and decorations are almost beyond human craftsmanship.
The monks are pure and diligent in their practice.
In the Buddha hall of East Zhaohuli, there is a piece of jade stone, more than two feet wide, with a yellowish-white color, shaped like a sea clam.
On it are the footprints of the Buddha, 1.8 chi long and over 6 chi wide.
On fasting days, it sometimes emits a bright light.
Outside the west gate of the great city, there are standing Buddha images on the left and right of the road, over 90 feet tall.
In front of these images, a place for the great assembly every five years is established.
Every autumn, for several tens of days, all the monks of the country gather here.
From the king above to the common people below, they abandoned worldly affairs, observed the precepts, received the sÅ«tras, and listened to the Dharma, forgetting their fatigue throughout the day.

The various monasteries adorned the Buddha images, polishing them with precious jewels and decorating them with brocade, carrying them in carriages, calling them traveling images, moving in the thousands, gathering like clouds at the assembly site.
On the fifteenth day of each month and the day of the new moon, the king and ministers discussed state affairs and consulted with eminent monks before making announcements.
Crossing the river to the northwest of the assembly site, one reaches the AÅ›rÄ«ka Monastery (meaning wondrous).
The courtyard is grand, and the Buddha images are skillfully decorated.
The monks are solemn and diligent, never slacking off. They are all elders of virtue, great scholars of high talent, and outstanding scholars from distant lands who have come to study the principles.
The king, ministers, officials, common people, and wealthy families make offerings of the four necessities for a long time, and their respect increases.
According to what I heard from the elders:

In the past, the previous king of this country revered the Three Jewels. He was about to travel to various places to pay homage to the holy traces, so he ordered his younger brother to take charge of the affairs while he was away.
His younger brother, having received the order, secretly castrated himself to prevent any future troubles.
He sealed it in a golden box and presented it to the king.
The king said:
What does this mean?
He replied:
It can be opened on the day the royal carriage returns.
He then handed it over to the attendant to guard it with the army.
When the king returned, there was indeed someone who caused trouble, saying:
The king ordered the regent to commit lewdness in the inner palace.
When the king heard this, he was greatly enraged and wanted to impose severe punishment.
The younger brother said:
I dare not escape punishment, but I wish to open the golden box.
The king then opened it and saw that it was his castrated organ.
He said:
What is this strange thing?
What do you want to make clear?
He replied:
When the king was traveling, he ordered me to stay behind. Fearing slander and misfortune, I castrated myself to prove my innocence.
Now there is indeed evidence. I hope you will investigate it.
The king was deeply surprised and his affection for him increased. He entered and left the inner court without any prohibition or obstruction.
Later, the king's younger brother encountered a man leading five hundred cows, intending to slaughter them.
Seeing this, he thought of his own situation and his feelings increased:
My current physical deficiency, is it not due to past karma?
He then redeemed the herd of cows with his wealth and treasures.
By the power of his compassionate kindness, his male form gradually became complete.
Because his form was complete, he finally did not enter the palace.
The king wondered about this and asked him, so he explained the beginning and end.
The king considered it extraordinary, so he built a monastery to commemorate his beautiful deeds, transmitting his fame to later generations.
From here going west for more than six hundred li, passing a small sandy desert, to the country of Baluka (formerly called Guhei, also called Qihei).
The country of Baluka is more than 600 li from east to west and more than 300 li from south to north.
The capital city of the country is five or six li in circumference.
The land and climate, human nature and customs, written language and rules are the same as in the Khotan country, but the language is slightly different.
Fine felt and fine cotton cloth are valued by neighboring countries.
There are dozens of monasteries with over a thousand monks, who study the teachings of the Hinayana school of the Sarvastivadins.
Traveling northwest from the country for more than 300 li, crossing a stone desert, one reaches the Ling Mountains.
This is the northern foothills of the Pamirs, where the water mostly flows east.
The valleys are filled with snow, frozen in spring and summer. Although sometimes melted, they soon freeze again.
The roads are dangerous and the cold wind is fierce.
There are many violent dragons that harm travelers.
Those who take this route are not allowed to wear red robes, carry gourds, or shout loudly.
If there is the slightest violation, disasters are seen with one's own eyes.
A violent storm arose, blowing sand and raining stones. Those who encountered it perished, and it was difficult to survive.
Traveling for more than 400 li in the mountains, they reached the Great Clear Pool, also called the Hot Sea or the Salty Sea.
It is over 1,000 li in circumference, long from east to west and narrow from south to north.

Surrounded by mountains on four sides, many streams converge. The color is tinged with blue-black, and the taste is a combination of salty and bitter. The great waves are vast and surging, with startling waves churning.

Dragons and fish mingle, and strange spiritual beings appear from time to time. Therefore, travelers who come and go pray for blessings. Although there are many aquatic creatures, no one dares to fish or catch them.
Traveling more than 500 li northwest from the Clear Pool, they reached the city of Suye Water.
The city is 6 to 7 li in circumference, and merchants and Hu people from various countries live there.

The climate is windy and cold, and the people wear felt and hemp clothes.
West of Suyab, there are dozens of isolated cities, each with its own ruler. Although they do not obey each other's orders, they are all subject to the Tujue.
From the water city of Suyab to the country of Karashahr, the local name is Shuli, and the people are also called that.
The written language and spoken language are also called accordingly.

The source of the characters is concise, originally consisting of more than twenty words, which transform and give rise to each other, and their flow gradually expands. There are rough written records, which are read vertically. They are passed down from teacher to student without interruption.
They wear felt and hemp, and clothes made of animal skins and cotton, with narrow and tight skirts.

They keep their hair in a queue and expose their heads, or shave their heads completely. Silk ribbons are tied on their foreheads. Their appearance is majestic, but their temperament is timid. Their customs are corrupt, and they often engage in deception. They are generally greedy, with fathers and sons calculating profits together. Those with much wealth are considered noble, and there is no distinction between good and bad.
Even if they are very wealthy, their clothing and food are coarse and poor.
Half of those who work in the fields and pursue profit are mixed in.
Going west from Suye for more than 400 li, he reached Qianshui.
Qianshui is over 200 li square, facing the Snow Mountains to the south, and flat land on three sides.
The water and soil are fertile, and the trees are lush. In the spring months, the flowers are like brocade.
There are a thousand springs and ponds, hence the name.
The Khan of the Turks often came here to escape the heat.
Among them were herds of deer, many adorned with bells and bracelets, tame to people, not running away in great fright.
The Khan loved and admired them, and issued an order to his subjects, daring to kill them, to be executed without pardon.
Thus, these herds of deer were able to live out their natural lives.
Going west from Qianshui for 140-50 li, he reached the city of Talas.
The city is 8-9 li in circumference, with merchants and Hu people from various countries living together.
The soil and climate are largely the same as Suye.

Going south for more than ten li, there is a small isolated city with over three hundred households, originally from China. In the past, they were captured by the Tujue and later gathered together in the same country, jointly protecting this city and living in it.

The products of the land and the climate are even better than in Dalasi.

The country of Nuojicheng is over one thousand li in circumference.
The land is fertile, with abundant crops, lush vegetation, and abundant flowers and fruits, with many grapes, which are also considered valuable.
There are hundreds of cities, each with its own ruler, coming and going without reporting to each other.

The country of Ledu is over four thousand li in circumference, surrounded by mountains on four sides.
The land is fertile, with abundant crops, many flowers and fruits, and is suitable for raising sheep and horses.
The climate is windy and cold, and the people are fierce and brave by nature. Their language is different from that of other countries, and their appearance is ugly.

For several decades, there has been no great ruler, and powerful chiefs compete with each other, not submitting to each other. They follow the rivers and occupy the dangerous terrain, dividing the land into different areas.

From here going northwest into the great sandy desert, there is no water or grass at all.
The road stretches far and wide, and the boundaries are difficult to measure. Looking at the great mountains, following the left bones, to know the direction, to record the journey.
Traveling for more than five hundred li, he reached the country of Samarkand (meaning healthy country in Tang).
The country of Samarkand is about one thousand six or seven hundred li in circumference, long from east to west and narrow from south to north.
The capital city is over twenty li in circumference and is extremely secure, with many inhabitants.

Among all the Hu countries, this is the center, and the etiquette and deportment of the people serve as a model for the neighboring countries.
The king is powerful and neighboring countries obey his orders.
His army is strong, with many Uighurs.
The Uighurs are by nature brave and fearless of death, and they are invincible in battle.
From here going southeast, he reached the country of Mimaka (meaning rice country in Tang).
The country of Mima is four or five hundred li in circumference.
It is located in a valley, narrow from east to west and long from south to north.
The land and customs are the same as in the country of Samarkand.
From here going north, one reaches the country of Kabuá¸a-nÄ.

From this country to the west for more than 400 li, it reaches the country of Buhe (meaning to guard and be at ease).
The country of Buhe is 1,670 li in circumference, long from east to west and narrow from south to north.
The soil and customs are the same as in Samarkand.
From this country to the west for more than 400 li, it reaches the country of Fudi (meaning to the west of An).
The country of Fudi is more than 400 li in circumference, and the soil and customs are the same as in Samarkand.
From here to the southwest for more than 500 li, it reaches the country of Hulixi Miguo.
The country of Hulixi Miguo is along both banks of the Oxus River, 20 to 30 li from east to west and more than 500 li from south to north.
The soil and customs are the same as in the country of Fudi, but the language is slightly different.
Going southwest from the country of Samarkand for more than three hundred li, he reached the country of Kasha.
The country of Kasha is one thousand four to five hundred li in circumference.
The land and customs are the same as in the country of Samarkand.
Going southwest from here for more than two hundred li, he entered the mountains.
The mountain roads are winding, the valleys dangerous, and there are few people and little water and grass.
Going southeast in the mountains for more than three hundred li, he entered the Iron Gate.

The Iron Gate is flanked by mountains on the left and right, the mountains are extremely steep, and although there is a narrow path, it is even more dangerous and perilous. The stone walls on both sides are the color of iron.
Doors have been set up and iron bolts are used. There are many iron bells hanging on the doors. Because of its dangerous solidity, it has become famous.
Coming out of the Iron Gate, he reached the country of Tukhara, which is called the country of Tuhua in ancient times, but this is a mistake.
The land is over a thousand li from south to north and over three thousand li from east to west.

In the east, it borders the Pamir Mountains, in the west, it borders Persia, in the south, it borders the Great Snow Mountains, and in the north, it borders the Iron Gate. The Vakshu River flows westward through the middle of the country.

For several hundred years, the royal lineage has been extinct, and powerful chieftains have competed with each other, each claiming to be the ruler. Relying on the rivers and taking advantage of the dangerous terrain, they have divided the country into twenty-seven states.
Although the territory is divided, they are all subject to the Tujue people.
The climate is warm, but there are also many diseases.
At the end of winter and the beginning of spring, there are continuous rainy days.
Therefore, to the south of this region and north of Lampaka, the climate and customs of the countries are mostly warm and humid.

The monks enter the rainy season retreat on the sixteenth day of the twelfth month and end the rainy season retreat on the fifteenth day of the third month. This is based on the frequent rains and is also a teaching that adapts to the changing seasons.
As for their customs, they are timid and cowardly;
Their appearance is ugly, but they have a rough understanding of loyalty and righteousness, and are not very deceitful.
Their language and behavior are slightly different from other countries.

The source of their characters consists of twenty-five letters, which transform and give rise to each other, and are used to cover all things. Their writing is read horizontally, from left to right. As their written records gradually increase, they become more extensive than in SÅ«li.
Most people wear cotton, and few wear coarse cloth.
They use gold, silver, and other coins as currency, and their molds are different from those of other countries.

The capital of the country is over twenty li in circuit.
